poem:
**Survivor's Tale**

In the furnace's fiery embrace,  
Jimmy shoveled coal, blackened wraith beneath the decks.  
Titanic's heart stalled, North Atlantic's grip tightened.  
An overturned raft, his fragile salvation,  
while icy echoes swallowed the screams,  
and the ocean's breath whispered the sinking's dirge.  
Sooted hands clutching hope,  
Jimmy watched as history sank beside him.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It was filthy, horrible work’: actors Paul and Stephen McGann reveal how their great uncle survived the Titanic Clinging to an overturned raft in the perilous, frozen waters of the north Atlantic, Jimmy McGann witnessed the horror of the 1912 sinking of the Titanic. He was one of its soot-covered coal-trimmers, toiling in blazing heat, shovelling coal into furnaces that powered the mighty vessel. Jimmy stayed aboard with the captain until the ship’s last moments". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
